title: East Africa: Impact Investors Are the New Samaritans
text:
Ethiopia: Over 20 Ministers, Investors to Convene for Key Energy Talks 
That they teach people how to fend for themselves rather than give them a meal for a day puts them on a plane above the corporate social responsibility programmes of many a corporation and the charitable actions of individual philanthropists and foundations. 
The study found East Africa has received about $9.3 billion in impact investment funds over the past five years, making it one of the hotspots of such ventures on the continent. A key regret is that the inflows would have been higher were it not for a dearth of investment-ready opportunities. 
To blame is the traditional way of running businesses by entrepreneurs -- without basics like record-keeping, a semblance of market research and a vision of where the business is headed. 
The other constraint is picking relatives and acquaintances for roles they are hardly qualified for in startups. With the set-up not inspiring confidence that the business will be well run, impact investors turn their backs and continue their search. 
East African countries should come together and lay a strong foundation for start-ups to capture the attention of impact investors, resolving a key hindrance to their growth -- expensive and often hard-to-arrange bank debt. 
One way they can help in this is to set up business incubation centres that teach entrepreneurs the basics of managing a business, keeping records, marketing and pitching for capital. Governments are trying in their own way, with the help of community-based organisations, to inculcate these values. 
High demand, however, has seen the proliferation of briefcase consultants, often riding on knowledge downloaded from the Internet. 
Another way governments could support the growth of impact investments is to relax the requirements for replication of invested activities across the region under the Common Market. 
This would increase the potential for higher returns attracting impact investors. Beyond governments, however, startups have to find a way through the labyrinth of challenges they face to stand out and be noticed by the right kind of suitors. East Africa
